sub_title: Full Professor and Chair Information Technology
summary:
Professor Tekinerdogan is a computer scientist with over 25 years of experience in software/systems engineering and information technology. He earned both his MSc degree (1994) and a PhD degree (2000) in Computer Science from the University of Twente, The Netherlands.

He was a faculty member at the University of Twente from 2003 to 2008 before joining Bilkent University, where he worked until 2015. At Bilkent University, he founded and led the Bilkent Software Engineering Group to promote software engineering research and education in Turkey. He is currently a full professor and chair of the Information Technology group at Wageningen University in The Netherlands.

Throughout his career, he has authored more than 400 peer-reviewed scientific papers and 8 edited books. He has been involved in dozens of national and international research and consultancy projects with various large software companies as a principal researcher and leading software/system architect. His experience spans a broad range of domains, including consumer electronics, enterprise systems, automotive systems, critical infrastructures, cyber-physical systems, satellite systems, defense systems, production line systems, command and control systems, physical protection systems, radar systems, smart metering systems, energy systems, and precision farming. He takes a holistic, systemic, and multi-disciplinary approach to solve real industrial problems and has ample experience in software and systems architecting, software and systems product line engineering, cyber-physical systems, model-driven software engineering, aspect-oriented software engineering, global software development, systems engineering, system of systems engineering, data science, and artificial intelligence.

In addition to his research, he is an active educator. He has developed and taught around 20 different academic courses and provided many software/systems engineering courses to more than 50 companies in The Netherlands, Germany, India, and Turkey. He has graduated more than 80 MSc students and supervised more than 25 PhD students. He is a regular reviewer for more than 20 international journals and has reviewed more than 100 national and international projects.

Prof. Tekinerdogan is also an active participant in scientific conferences and has organized more than 50 conferences/workshops on software engineering topics. He can communicate in English, Dutch, Turkish, French, and German.

treasury_media.title: Management and Engineering of Critical Infrastructures
treasury_media.description: Management and Engineering of Critical Infrastructures focuses on two important aspects of CIS, management and engineering. The book provides an ontological foundation for the models and methods needed to design a set of systems, networks and assets that are essential for a society's functioning, and for ensuring the security, safety and economy of a nation.

contributors.headline: Full Professor and Chair Information Technology

projects.title: Horizon 2020 Internet of Farm and Food
projects.description:
The internet of things (IoT) has revolutionary potential. A smart web of sensors, actuators, cameras, robots, drones and other connected devices allows for an unprecedented level of control and automated decision-making. The project Internet of Food & Farm 2020 (IoF2020) explores the potential of IoT-technologies for the European food and farming industry.

The goal is ambitious: to make precision farming a reality and to take a vital step towards a more sustainable food value chain. With the help of IoT technologies higher yields and better quality produce are within reach. Pesticide and fertilizer use will drop and overall efficiency is optimized. IoT technologies also enable better traceability of food, leading to increased food safety. 

IoF2020 is part of Horizon 2020 Industrial Leadership and supported by the European Commission with a budget of EUR 30 million. The aim of IoF2020 is to build a lasting innovation ecosystem that fosters the uptake of IoT technologies. For this purpose key stakeholders along the food value chain are involved in IoF2020 together with technology service providers, software companies and academic research institutions.

Nineteen use-cases organised around five sectors (arable, dairy, fruits, meat and vegetables) develop, test and demonstrate IoT technologies in an operational farm environment all over Europe.

contributors.headline: Full Professor and Chair Information Technology

projects.title: Horizon 2020-ICT COST Action IC1404 Multi-Paradigm Modelling for Cyber-Physical Systems (MPM4CPS)
projects.description:
Multi-Paradigm Modelling for Cyber-Physical Systems (MPM4CPS)
Truly complex, designed systems, known as Cyber Physical Systems (CPS), are emerging that integrate physical, software, and network aspects. To date, no unifying theory nor systematic design methods, techniques and tools exist for such systems. Individual (mechanical, electrical, network or software) engineering disciplines only offer partial solutions.

Multi-paradigm Modelling (MPM) proposes to model every part and aspect of a system explicitly, at the most appropriate level(s) of abstraction, using the most appropriate modelling formalism(s). Modelling languages’ engineering, including model transformation, and the study of their semantics, are used to realize MPM. MPM is seen as an effective answer to the challenges of designing CPS.

We aim to promote the sharing of foundations, techniques, and tools and to provide educational resources, to both academia and industry. This will be achieved by bringing together and disseminating knowledge and experiments on CPS problems and MPM solutions.

(Descriptions are provided by the Actions directly via e-COST.)

authors.headline: Full Professor and Chair Information Technology

courses.name: Information Systems for Managers and Engineers

profile_positions.description:
I serve as the Chairholder of the Information Technology Group, a diverse and dynamic team consisting of over 50 members, including 20 staff members, 5 post-doctoral researchers, and more than 25 PhD candidates. As the group leader, I am responsible for overseeing our research, education, and project acquisition efforts.

Our mission is to push the boundaries of smart systems and system-of-systems engineering, with a focus on advancing innovations in the life sciences. Our research domains include artificial intelligence,  data science, systems engineering, software engineering, and socio-technical systems.

Our Information Technology Group has achieved unprecedented growth and success under my leadership. In just a few years, we have expanded our team from 10 members to over 50 highly skilled individuals, including staff members, post-doctoral researchers, and PhD candidates.

We have also made remarkable and unprecedented progress in our research efforts, publishing an average of only 5 publications before my appointment, and now exceeding 75 publications in high-impact journals. In addition, we have significantly expanded our educational offerings, growing from just 12 courses to an impressive 35 courses in computer science and related fields. 

We have also taken an active role in the larger academic community, joining the management board of 4TU-NIRICT, the Dutch Association for Software Engineering (VERSEN), The Dutch AI Coalition, and the Big Data Alliance Group. We have also established collaborations with other technical universities in the Netherlands and hired several post-doctoral researchers from various research projects.

Our group has also achieved financial stability, allowing us to focus on pursuing our research goals without any distractions. 

We are always eager to explore new collaborations and welcome any ideas for potential partnerships.
profile_positions.title: Full Professor and Chair Information Technology

profile_positions.description:
In addition to my position as Chair of the Information Technology Group, I serve as the Chair of the Business Science Section at Wageningen University & Research. This vibrant and dynamic section is comprised of five robust chair groups, each with its own distinct expertise, including Information Technology, Business Economics, Business Management & Organization, Marketing and Consumer Behavior, and Operations Research and Logistics.

Our collective mission is to promote collaborative research and innovation in the field of sustainable business science and engineering. We pride ourselves on our interdisciplinary approach, drawing on a wide range of knowledge and expertise to tackle complex challenges and produce innovative solutions.

As Chair of this esteemed section, I am committed to fostering a culture of excellence, collaboration, and creativity. Together, we are dedicated to advancing the field of business science, and to creating a brighter, more sustainable future for all.
profile_positions.title: Full Professor and Chair Business Science Section

profile_positions.description:
Over the past 25 years, I have provided education, research, and consultancy services to many large-scale companies in the field of software and systems engineering in various countries. My consultancy work has focused on helping organizations optimize their software and systems engineering processes, and develop and implement best practices that align with their business goals and objectives. As a researcher and professional consultant, I have conducted assessments of software and systems engineering processes, identified areas for improvement, and provided recommendations for enhancing efficiency, reliability, and quality. I have done projects in many applications domains related to topics such as systems and software product line engineering, architecture design, model-driven development, software and systems process engineering, aspect-oriented software engineering, and many other topics.

I have also worked with organizations to develop and deliver customized training programs to help their employees develop the skills and knowledge needed to excel in software and systems engineering.  
I have designed and delivered more than 20 different customized courses on software and systems engineering, tailored to the specific needs of the organization. These courses have provided employees with the skills and knowledge needed to excel in software and systems engineering, and have helped organizations to achieve their business goals and objectives. 

Through my consultancy work, I have helped many organizations to achieve significant improvements in their software and systems engineering processes, resulting in increased productivity, cost savings, and higher-quality outputs. I have helped organizations to stay ahead of the curve in a rapidly-evolving technological landscape, by introducing them to the latest trends, techniques, and tools in the field of software and systems engineering. 

Don't hesitate to contact me in case of collaboration opportunities.
profile_positions.title: Education, Research & Consultancy Activities

profile_positions.description:
AMS Institute (Amsterdam Institute for Advanced Metropolitan Solutions) is a collaboration between Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Wageningen University & Research, Delft University of Technology, the City of Amsterdam.

Launched in 2013, AMS Institute is a young public-private institute based in Amsterdam. Situated at the nexus between industry, government and academia, our mission is to free intelligence from its ivory tower and let it out into the world where it can do something useful. 

Aiming to solve problems in metropolitan areas, we combine brainpower, data and knowledge from the fields of design, planning, life sciences, engineering, physics, mathematics, information technology and social sciences. Through facilitating and initiating (research)projects that ‘fix’ things we create practical solutions, products, businesses activity and workable plans that benefit urban progress.

Website
http://www.ams-institute.org
profile_positions.title: Principal Investigator - Amsterdam Institute for Advanced Metropolitan Solutions

profile_positions.title: Solutions Expert/Consultant/Professional Teacher

profile_positions.description:
• Awarded the rank of Associate Professor by the Turkish Inter-University Council in 2010
• Received IBM Faculty Award nominations in 2009 and 2010
• Founded and led the Bilkent Software Engineering Group (Bilsen)
• Introduced and taught a total of 8 different software engineering courses, receiving an average teaching effectiveness rating of 4.7 out of 5
• Successfully supervised 8 PhD students and served on the PhD evaluation committees of 6 students at METU, Hacettepe, and Ege Universities
• Acted as supervisor for over 12 MSc students and advisor for more than 70 students
• Organized eight national workshops and four international workshops, and served as PC Chair for the 3rd Turkish Software Architecture Conference, the 6th Turkish Software Engineering Conference in 2012, and the 5th Turkish Software Architecture Conference in 2014
• Presented dozens of invited seminars to the Turkish industry
• Served as a PC member for over 50 conferences/workshops and reviewed manuscripts for over 15 journals and four books
• Evaluated ICT projects as a Scientific Committee Member for the Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TUBITAK) and reviewed more than 50 national projects for TUBITAK
• Served as Steering Committee Chair of the Turkish Software Architecture Design Conferences since 2006 and as a Steering Committee Member of the Early Aspects Group
• Participated in three FP7 project proposals and joined two ITEA2 project proposals
• Successfully supervised 12 senior design projects
• Achieved finalist and third prize in the Microsoft Imagine Cup Turkey contest in 2010 and 2011 respectively, and won third prize (2010) and second prize (2011) in the IBM Software Academy Turkey competition
• Won the best Microsoft Senior Design project in the department twice (2010, 2011) and received the Presentation Award in 2012 and 2013
• Consultant for various Turkish IT companies such as Havelsan, Aselsan, Meteksan Defense, Vestel, TAI, and Cybersoft
profile_positions.title: Faculty Professor

profile_positions.description:
My research and education activities were focused on software architecture and related topics, including aspect-oriented software architecture design, software architecture modeling, software architecture methods, software architecture analysis, software product line architectures, model-driven software development, and architectural reliability analysis. I have been fortunate enough to be involved in several significant projects and supervise a number of talented PhD students and postdocs.

In particular, I was involved in three different projects that have had a significant impact on the field of software engineering. These included the Television Related Architecture Design for Reliability (Trader project), which was primarily coordinated by the Embedded Systems Institute and Philips and involved supervising two PhD students. Additionally, I was involved in an Aspect-Oriented Software Architecture Design project, which was funded by the Jacquard program of the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research (NWO) and involved supervising one PhD student. Finally, I participated in the European Network of Excellence on Aspect-Oriented Software Development project, where I supervised one postdoc.

In addition to my academic activities, I have also carried out consultancy and education activities for the industry, where I have been able to apply my expertise and contribute to the development of practical solutions to real-world challenges.
profile_positions.title: Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description:
During my sabbatical leave, I had the opportunity to contribute to the academic community at Bilkent University in a variety of ways. In particular, I introduced and taught several courses, including Software Architecture Design (2), Aspect-Oriented Software Development, and Object-Oriented Programming. Through these courses, I aimed to provide students with a solid foundation in software engineering principles, and to inspire them to explore new and innovative approaches to software development.

In addition to teaching, I also organized several workshops that were well-received by the academic community. I am particularly proud of the Aspect-Oriented Software Development workshop, which was the first of its kind in Turkey and attracted a significant amount of interest from students and industry professionals alike. I also organized the Impact of Process on Software Quality workshop, which aimed to explore the role of software engineering processes in ensuring the quality of software development projects.

In addition to my teaching and workshop activities, I also supervised several BSc and MSc students, providing guidance and mentorship as they pursued their academic and professional goals. I also reviewed many software engineering projects for the Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey (TÜBITAK), where I was able to contribute my expertise and help evaluate the quality and impact of various software development projects.
profile_positions.title: Visiting Assistant Professor

profile_positions.description:
During my time working on the project funded by the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research NWO, I focused on the important area of inconsistency management in object-oriented design and software architecture design. Through my research, I sought to develop innovative approaches to this complex challenge, leveraging cutting-edge techniques and methodologies to achieve meaningful results.

In particular, I applied fuzzy engineering techniques to cope with inconsistencies, developing an approach that has the potential to significantly improve the reliability and effectiveness of software engineering processes. I was able to demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach through a series of experiments and case studies, which resulted in a number of important publications that have been widely cited in the field.

One of the key applications of this approach was in the scoping of knowledge sources in domain analysis. By leveraging fuzzy engineering techniques to manage inconsistencies and improve the reliability of our knowledge sources, we were able to achieve significant improvements in the accuracy and effectiveness of our analyses. This work has significant implications for a wide range of software engineering applications, and has the potential to contribute to meaningful advances in the field.
profile_positions.title: Post-doc

profile_positions.description:
My PhD research activities were carried out in the dynamic and challenging context of Siemens-Nixdorf, where I focused on designing software architectures for adaptable transaction systems in the car dealer management industry. Over the course of four years, I had the privilege of regularly meeting with researchers and engineers at Siemens-Nixdorf, collaborating with them to develop innovative solutions to complex software engineering challenges.

During this time, I explored a wide range of topics, including software engineering, problem solving, software architecture design methods, quality modeling in software design, and design space modeling. My research resulted in the Synthesis-Based Software Architecture Design Method, which we applied to design an adaptable transaction system architecture for the car dealer management system of Siemens-Nixdorf. This approach was highly effective, and resulted in significant improvements in the efficiency, reliability, and effectiveness of the software engineering process.

Importantly, my PhD thesis also pioneered the use of the term "domain-driven design", which has since become a widely recognized and influential concept in the field of software engineering. This term refers to an approach that prioritizes the needs and requirements of specific domains when designing software architectures, resulting in more effective, targeted, and sustainable solutions.
profile_positions.title: PhD Associate

profile_positions.description:
I was appointed as a researcher on the Intelligent Tutoring Systems for Executable Languages project (ITSSEL), which was a collaborative effort between the departments of computer science and education. In my role as primary researcher, I designed an intelligent tutoring shell system for teaching imperative programming languages, and played a critical role in the development of the Reflective Intelligent Tutoring System. The Reflective Intelligent Tutoring System that I helped to develop was a sophisticated software tool that could provide real-time feedback, guidance, and support, helping to ensure that students and programmers are able to complete their work quickly, efficiently, and accurately.

Thanks to the success of this project, we were able to publish three research papers that provide contributions to the development of effective tutoring systems for teaching imperative programming languages.
profile_positions.title: Research Associate
